name: Chris Sununu

name: Chris Sununu
tweet: One year ago, the first case of COVID-19 was diagnosed in NH. With the arrival of vaccines and a decline in cases, hospitalizations, and deaths, we continue to be on a great track. name: Chris Sununu
tweet: THREAD: Today I joined a bipartisan group of 21 other governors raising the alarm over the $1.9 trillion COVID relief bill. Its passage would send the unmistakable message that Washington politicians expect New Hampshire taxpayers to subsidize poorly run, cash-strapped states.

name: Chris Sununu
tweet: Minimizing hospitalizations and deaths has always been our main goal in the fight against COVID ‚Äî and that‚Äôs exactly why the vaccines are so important. News that a third vaccine may come online next week, along with increased weekly shipments, is welcome news.  https://t.co/oUOdfV1NNj

name: Chris Sununu
tweet: In accordance with the proclamation issued by @POTUS, I‚Äôve directed all flags on public buildings and grounds in NH to fly at half-staff until sunset on February 26, 2021 in remembrance of the 500,000 Americans and 1,154 Granite Staters who have died from COVID-19.

name: Chris Sununu
tweet: To be sure, aside from COVID we continue to have great policy challenges ahead of us. I'll keep fighting to deliver meaningful results for Granite Staters.  https://t.co/ORNuPOq5Ka

name: Chris Sununu
tweet: Per @cdcgov, NH is among the top states in the nation for the number of COVID vaccines administered. name: Chris Sununu
tweet: Wearing a mask isn‚Äôt about you ‚Äî it‚Äôs about protecting your neighbors, your family, and our most vulnerable citizens. That‚Äôs why we do it.   Joined @AnaCabrera on CNN tonight to talk COVID safety measures.  https://t.co/yAD8EclprZ

name: Chris Sununu
tweet: As we ring in the New Year, we have plenty of reason to celebrate as today marks the first day of no active COVID cases at the Veterans Home in Tilton since an outbreak began. GREAT news to start off 2021. The end of this pandemic is in sight.  https://t.co/oYe2h5bOZD

name: Chris Sununu

name: Chris Sununu
tweet: Today we are announcing a $4 million investment in @UofNH's COVID-19 testing infrastructure. The University System has been an important partner throughout this crisis and this investment will help them even further.  https://t.co/H9qxDnOdzh

name: Chris Sununu
tweet: Last week I spoke with @HHSGov and urged swift action to move forward with Phase 3 of COVID-19 Provider Relief Funding. Thrilled that $77M is on its way to New Hampshire. /1

name: Chris Sununu
tweet: We still have a long ways to go, but with the first COVID-19 vaccine administered in New Hampshire this morning, we can finally see the light at the end of the tunnel.  https://t.co/Ge78u1Esv6

name: Chris Sununu
tweet: The job in congress ain‚Äôt that hard, but let‚Äôs be clear: congress hasn‚Äôt done anything in the last 8 months to provide the American people and states with COVID relief. Watch what I had to say on @MeetThePress with @chucktodd.  https://t.co/XgIZHlLP1v

name: Chris Sununu
tweet: I thank the member of my team for immediately quarantining and following all public health guidance, and wish them good health as they recover from COVID-19. (3/3)

name: Chris Sununu
tweet: Today, a member of my staff tested positive for COVID-19. Transparency is paramount in public health crises, and this is no exception. Like many workplaces across the state and country, the State House is not immune.

name: Chris Sununu
tweet: That @US_FDA approval of a COVID-19 vaccine may be just around the corner is welcome news, and NH stands ready to move those shipments out the door the very next day. In the meantime, we‚Äôll keep practicing what we know to work. Wear a mask, social distance, and wash your hands.  https://t.co/3dTgxMAj6J

name: Chris Sununu
tweet: No one intends to get COVID, and no one intends to spread it to others. Here are some things to keep in mind as we head towards Thanksgiving.  https://t.co/PVCmuJdHN0

name: Chris Sununu
tweet: If you don‚Äôt wear a mask into a store and are asymptomatically spreading COVID, you risk shutting down that business for weeks, you risk unknowingly infecting someone with severe health issues or someone who works on a longterm care facility.

name: Chris Sununu
tweet: As we all know, COVID does not stop at any one town‚Äôs borders. With substantial community spread across the entire state ‚Äì including in Coos County ‚Äì where the city of Berlin just instituted a mask mandate of their own, we are making this decision at a statewide level.

name: Chris Sununu
tweet: We now have substantial community transmission throughout our entire state. Early on, the pandemic had a disproportionate impact on the southern counties while the northern, more rural counties had less prevalence of COVID.

name: Chris Sununu
tweet: Through this crisis, the state has remained consistent in urging folks to wear masks. They work, they help prevent the spread of COVID, and people should wear them. We have said all along that a mask mandate was always on the table, and that we would let data drive our decisions.

name: Chris Sununu
tweet: We can start by going over the background on this issue and how we got to where we are today. Through this crisis, the state has remained consistent in urging folks to wear masks. They work, they help prevent the spread of COVID, and people should wear them.

name: Chris Sununu
tweet: Our Housing Relief Fund, which was designed to keep people from losing their housing and to secure or maintain permanent housing, remains open. Households unable to pay rent due to COVID related issues are eligible for these funds. Visit  https://t.co/Acrx6QGy3T to learn more.

name: Chris Sununu
tweet: THREAD: Today New Hampshire is reporting 205 cases of COVID-19. The situation here remains very serious, the data shows that community transmission is increasing, and we expect cases to rise. (1/2)

name: Chris Sununu
tweet: Since the onset of COVID-19 in March, schools have served over 6.5 MILLION meals to students across the state. More than 4.2 million of those have been served free of charge to students - an increase of more than 300,000 compared to the same period last year.  https://t.co/c3hfzWSXYz

name: Chris Sununu
tweet: THREAD: At the request of the @NHLRA, starting this Sat., 10/31, restaurants will be required to collect simple information from patrons - a name, phone number, & time of arrival - to assist the state's contact tracing team in alerting those who may have been exposed to COVID-19.  https://t.co/upqBoRNhPu

name: Chris Sununu
tweet: Whether it‚Äôs sentinel testing in our nursing homes, our new First Responder Screening Program, or the new availability of Binax Rapid Tests, we're better equipped than ever to understand the reach of COVID-19 and respond in a quick, targeted fashion to limit further spread. (/2)

name: Chris Sununu
tweet: Pretty amazing to see how restaurants are innovating through COVID. The @RedFoxBarGrille is the largest restaurant in Jackson and they built out a brand new take-out counter to help keep business going. The cannoli‚Äôs were amazing!  https://t.co/IQ4uDbyVz4

name: Chris Sununu
tweet: While NH has the third lowest rate of COVID-19 cases per capita among US States, we have now had 10,000 confirmed cases since March. NH has managed this pandemic well and we will continue to do so.  Stay vigilant. Wear a mask. Social distance. Practice good hand hygiene.

name: Chris Sununu
tweet: The negative impacts of COVID-19 on our veterans has been well documented. Earlier this year we allocated $7M to ensure veterans continued to receive vital services & community supports. Today, we are proud to announce an additional investment of $2M to help meet remaining needs.  https://t.co/dLsg0LQOwr

name: Chris Sununu
tweet: We are grateful to the management of LRG Healthcare and Concord Hospital, who have been working on this potential acquisition since before the onset of the Covid-19 pandemic. (1/3)

name: Chris Sununu
tweet: Today we are also announcing an additional $7M for PPE and testing in long-term care facilities. We know the health consequences of COVID on our older populations can be severe, and we therefore continue to take quick actions to protect residents and staff in these facilities.  https://t.co/3dK22EvQzA

name: Chris Sununu
tweet: Had the Democrats won this case six months ago, our COVID relief efforts would have stalled, negatively impacting every citizen of NH. I am thankful for the ruling, but it is unfortunate so many state resources were wasted defending this failed lawsuit by Democrat leadership.

name: Chris Sununu
tweet: Pleased to welcome Ambassador Debbie Birx to New Hampshire today to discuss the steps we‚Äôve taken to combat COVID-19 here in the Granite State, tour @UofNH‚Äôs testing lab, and meet with University officials for a roundtable discussion.  https://t.co/MjcP0zef4w

name: Chris Sununu
tweet: Click below to view all of our open COVID-19 relief programs and submit your application today.

name: Chris Sununu
tweet: In March, we created the Child Care Recovery & Stabilization Program to provide support for COVID-19 related costs. Today, we're announcing an additional $10M in financial support for those daycares that were part of this program on top of our original $28M investment.  https://t.co/UMohH3tw68

name: Chris Sununu
tweet: Our schools have responded to COVID cases that have come up exceptionally well. In the vast majority of instances where cases have occurred, local officials have worked closely with the team at Public Health to appropriately manage the situation and have done a good job. (3/3)

name: Chris Sununu
tweet: The state is still accepting applications for our Non-Dairy Farmer Relief Program, which allows non-dairy farms to apply for relief for COVID-19 related expenses and/or lost sales related to COVID between July 1 and September 30. Click below to learn more and apply.

name: Chris Sununu
tweet: These rapid tests can be done for anyone with a symptom of COVID-19, including K-12 students and teachers, frontline healthcare workers, emergency responders, and other high-risk populations. The tests are simple, portable, and produce results within 15 minutes. (/3)

name: Chris Sununu
tweet: Awesome time at the Girls at Work grand opening celebration yesterday ‚Äî an amazing NH organization that wont be slowed down by COVID and remote learning. The state is committing GEER funding so that Girls at Work can send their construction kits to hundreds across the state.  https://t.co/8DkhNXn2bs

name: Chris Sununu
tweet: Over the past several weeks we have made several appeals to cities & towns to apply for funding under the municipal and country program for COVID related expenses, including upgrades and supply purchases for schools in preparation for students to return to in-person classes. (/2)

name: Chris Sununu
tweet: The team at @nhgoferr and Business and Economic Affairs have already worked together to play a central effort in responding to the COVID-19 pandemic. We're excited for Taylor to continue this partnership and join GOFERR in this additional role. (/3)

mentions.name: governor's office for emergency relief & recovery

name: Chris Sununu
tweet: Our COVID-19 schools dashboard is now live. This centralized website lists every school across NH with information on the number of cases within the schools, if there are clusters of illness, and if the school has reached an outbreak status. View here:  https://t.co/MmxGfK0Kl8  https://t.co/ASLf6PkLIx

name: Chris Sununu
tweet: These comments articulate our serious policy and legal concerns with Granite Staters being taxed in MA when they have not crossed the state line in months due to COVID-19.

name: Chris Sununu
tweet: To review, here's what you can expect if a COVID case is identified within the school.  https://t.co/hmE5J28JKN

name: Chris Sununu
tweet: For example, let's say three students had close contact at lunch, after which COVID cases are identified within three classes because of that contact in the cafeteria. (3/3)  https://t.co/VIqdGh3RiX

name: Chris Sununu
tweet: THREAD: If COVID is identified in a school we will designate two statuses: Clusters of Illness and an Outbreak.   A cluster is when three or more positive cases are identified within one class. Schools will notify their communities of a cluster and contact tracing will follow.  https://t.co/aiOx9JL3NL

name: Chris Sununu
tweet: If there are new COVID positive cases identified in a new part of a school, like a new grade, school officials with notify their community. The level of detail released will be dependent upon how large the grade is and how much contact the individual had with others. (5/5)  https://t.co/Nz17ODrG9h

name: Chris Sununu
tweet: Individuals who are identified as a close contact of someone who‚Äôs tested positive for COVID will be asked to stay home for 14 days after their last exposure, monitor for symptoms, and be tested. (/4)

name: Chris Sununu
tweet: THREAD: The Safer Scholars Campus Modification Program will assist private, non-profit colleges and universities as they modify their operations in light of COVID-19 and prepare to reopen their campuses to students this fall. Click below to apply.

name: Chris Sununu
tweet: THREAD: We know that long term care facilities have faced the brunt of the #COVID19 crisis in NH ‚Äì and today we're announcing that the state will be undergoing a two week review of all long-term-care facilities that have had an outbreak of COVID-19.

name: Chris Sununu
tweet: The highlights of the guidance include:  ‚û°Ô∏èRobust daily screening process for staff, students and visitors for symptoms of COVID-19 or risk factors for exposure prior to entering the educational facility.  (7/)

name: Chris Sununu
tweet: To date, 88,647 Granite Staters have been tested for #COVID19, with 5,132 confirmed cases in the State. Thankfully, 3,501 individuals have recovered.  Our deepest condolences and prayers are with the family and friends of the 286 Granite Staters that we have lost to COVID-19.

name: Chris Sununu
tweet: Throughout the #COVID19 pandemic we've managed our health care capacity incredibly well. On average, less than 5% of available hospital beds have been occupied by COVID-19 patients. This is another data point which provides us with additional flexibility moving forward. (2/2)  https://t.co/q0XxTdCXdn

name: Chris Sununu
tweet: Today we are reporting out 1,900 #COVID19 test results ‚Äî the highest number of tests conducted in a single day. Of those tests, 63, or 3.3% were positive for COVID-19. This is good news. Increased testing will continue to help guide our decisions moving forward.

name: Chris Sununu
tweet: Every day we are taking significant steps forward in expanding access to #COVID19 testing. Our new portal on  https://t.co/JT86ebGFjQ allows you to schedule yourself to receive a COVID-19 test. Watch below to see if you‚Äôre eligible:  https://t.co/AWRTE7a1MX

name: Chris Sununu
tweet: ‚û°Ô∏èProvide additional dollars directly to shelters to assist them with the increased costs they are faced with due to the COVID pandemic  ‚û°Ô∏èAdditional dollars will be provided to community agencies to support permanent housing for individuals and families experiencing homelessness

name: Chris Sununu
tweet: .@USTreasury guidance provides a great deal of flexibility to use these funds to provide relief for COVID expenses incurred by small businesses, non-profits, & public institutions - all of which are areas the Governor‚Äôs Office for Emergency Relief & Recovery will examine. (3/6)

name: Chris Sununu
tweet: I‚Äôll be holding a press conference today at 3 PM to provide an update on the state‚Äôs response to COVID-19. Watch live:  https://t.co/23YE0YT43Q

name: Chris Sununu
tweet: Over the last few weeks, the state has taken unprecedented action in responding to the COVID-19 outbreak. The decisions we have made are tough ‚Äî but they are consistently moving in step with the escalating COVID-19 crisis here in NH. Read my op-ed:  https://t.co/GQtsD4JTRU

name: Chris Sununu
tweet: Today‚Äôs study recognizes we are taking unprecedented and proactive steps. Testing is ramping up. And we are working around the clock to slow and mitigate the spread of COVID-19 here in New Hampshire.   https://t.co/QcwJ21fbRV

name: Chris Sununu
tweet: Today I issued an Emergency Order establishing the COVID-19 Emergency Healthcare System Relief Fund. This new initiative will help ensure the doors to our hospitals remain open, and that individuals can still get the health care they need.  https://t.co/YKhbNPRmqV

name: Chris Sununu
tweet: Today I issued an emergency order allowing for patrons to also order beer and wine from their favorite restaurants when ordering pickup or delivery. We appreciate the sacrifices many have made throughout COVID-19 developments.  https://t.co/rYwmAS3OFR

name: Chris Sununu
tweet: ‚û°Ô∏èIndividuals that need to care for a family member that has COVID-19 or is under quarantine. ‚û°Ô∏èIndividuals that need to care for a dependent because of school closures, child care facility closures or other similar types of care programs. (7/15)

name: Chris Sununu
tweet: ‚û°Ô∏èIf your employer temporarily closes due to COVID-19 ‚û°Ô∏èIndividuals that need to self-quarantine or are directed to quarantine at the instruction of a health care provider, employer or government official. (6/15)

name: Chris Sununu
tweet: THREE: We are breaking down barriers and wait times and expanding access to unemployment benefits. The order I am issuing will allow individuals who are unable to work or who have reduced hours due to the COVID-19 pandemic to access unemployment benefits. (4/15)

name: Chris Sununu
tweet: Today I am issuing three additional Emergency Orders that will help provide relief for those affected by COVID-19. We are taking steps to help Granite Staters, ensuring they have support & services for themselves, their families, & their businesses throughout this crisis. (1/15)

name: Chris Sununu
tweet: WATCH LIVE: This morning I am holding a press conference with legislative leaders and administration officials to announce steps we are taking to help Granite Staters affected by COVID-19 through executive action.  https://t.co/W1mJqDIDR5

name: Chris Sununu
tweet: Service industry employees affected by this temporary change will be able to qualify for unemployment benefits effective immediately tomorrow, where we will announce steps and set up a hotline and website for any worker adversely affected by the COVID-19 pandemic.

name: Chris Sununu
tweet: WATCH LIVE: I‚Äôm holding a press conference with Dept. of Health and Human Services Commissioner Lori Shibinette, @NHEdCommr Frank Edelblut, & State Officials to provide an update on COVID-19 and the status of schools in the Granite State.  https://t.co/8HRtYaec31

name: Chris Sununu
tweet: The State‚Äôs Emergency Operations Center has been activated, along with the 211NH hotline. Individuals with questions related to COVID-19, or who think they may be exhibiting symptoms, can dial 2-1-1. (4/4)

name: Chris Sununu
tweet: At this time, there remains a low risk to New Hampshire for COVID-19. We know there is no evidence to suggest that there is widespread community transmission. This declaration will allow the state to remain on top of this rapidly evolving situation. (2/4)

name: Chris Sununu
tweet: Any person who develops fever or respiratory symptoms (e.g., cough, shortness of breath) should stay home away from others and seek health advice by phone from a healthcare provider to discuss symptoms and any risk factors for COVID-19.

name: Chris Sununu
tweet: Despite increased testing in our communities, the NH DHHS has not yet identified any widespread transmission in NH nor individuals who test positive without clearly identified risk factors (e.g. travel or contact to a confirmed COVID-19 case).

name: Chris Sununu
tweet: Today I wrote to New Hampshire's Congressional Delegation to urge them to approve emergency appropriations being debated in Congress to help combat any potential outbreak of COVID-19 in NH & across the Country, and to inform them of NH's preparedness to handle any such outbreak.  https://t.co/AZlnisvSrm
